sections.content: Macronutrients—carbs, proteins, and fats—are nutrients your body needs in large amounts for energy, growth, and function. Understanding each type helps you make better food choices, optimize energy levels, and reach health goals. Quality matters more than quantity. This lesson breaks down each macronutrient and how to use them.

sections.title: Carbohydrates Explained
items: Function: Primary energy source, especially for brain and muscles
Simple carbs: Quick energy, spikes blood sugar (white bread, candy, soda)
Complex carbs: Sustained energy, stable blood sugar (whole grains, vegetables, legumes)
Fiber: Type of carb that aids digestion, keeps you full
Timing: Best before/after workouts for energy and recovery
Recommendation: 45-65% of daily calories from quality carbs
Choose: Whole grains, fruits, vegetables, legumes
Limit: Refined sugars, white bread, pastries

sections.title: Protein Essentials
items: Function: Builds and repairs muscles, tissues, enzymes, hormones
Amino acids: Building blocks of protein (9 essential from food)
Complete proteins: Contain all 9 essential (meat, fish, eggs, dairy, quinoa)
Incomplete: Missing some essential (most plant proteins)
Combine plant proteins: Rice + beans = complete
Amount: 0.8-1g per kg body weight (more if active/building muscle)
Distribute: 20-30g per meal better than all at once
Sources: Lean meats, fish, eggs, dairy, legumes, nuts, tofu

sections.title: Healthy Fats Guide
items: Function: Hormone production, brain health, nutrient absorption, satiety
Monounsaturated: Heart-healthy (olive oil, avocados, nuts)
Polyunsaturated: Omega-3 and omega-6 (fatty fish, flaxseeds, walnuts)
Saturated: Moderate amounts okay (coconut oil, butter, meat)
Trans fats: AVOID (partially hydrogenated oils, fried foods)
Omega-3s: Anti-inflammatory, brain health (salmon, sardines, chia)
Amount: 20-35% of daily calories from healthy fats
Quality matters: Choose whole food sources over processed oils

sections.content: The macronutrient ratio depends on your goals: Weight loss (higher protein/moderate carbs), Muscle gain (higher protein/carbs), Endurance (higher carbs), General health (balanced). No single ratio works for everyone. Start balanced (40% carbs, 30% protein, 30% fat), adjust based on how you feel and your results.

sections.title: Balancing Your Plate
items: ½ plate: Vegetables (non-starchy like broccoli, leafy greens)
¼ plate: Protein (palm-sized portion of meat/fish/plant protein)
¼ plate: Complex carbs (fist-sized portion of grains/starchy vegetables)
Fat: Thumb-sized portion (avocado, nuts, cooking oil)
Fruit: 1-2 servings daily
Adjust portions: Based on activity level and goals
Visual cues: Hand portions make tracking simple
Flexibility: Perfect balance every meal not required

quiz.question: What are complete proteins?
options: Proteins containing all 9 essential amino acids
quiz.explanation: Complete proteins contain all 9 essential amino acids your body can't produce. Found in meat, fish, eggs, dairy, quinoa. Plant proteins can be combined to create complete proteins.

quiz.question: Which type of fat should you avoid?
options: Trans fats from partially hydrogenated oils
quiz.explanation: Trans fats (partially hydrogenated oils) increase bad cholesterol and should be avoided. Healthy fats like monounsaturated, polyunsaturated, and moderate saturated fats are essential for health.

sections.content: Micronutrients—vitamins and minerals—are needed in small amounts but play massive roles in health. They don't provide energy but are essential for energy production, immune function, bone health, and disease prevention. Deficiencies cause serious problems. This lesson covers key micronutrients and how to get them through food.

sections.title: Essential Vitamins
items: Vitamin A: Vision, immune function (carrots, sweet potatoes, liver)
Vitamin C: Antioxidant, collagen production (citrus, berries, peppers)
Vitamin D: Bone health, mood (sunlight, fatty fish, fortified foods)
Vitamin E: Antioxidant, skin health (nuts, seeds, spinach)
Vitamin K: Blood clotting, bone health (leafy greens, broccoli)
B vitamins: Energy production, nerve function (whole grains, meat, eggs)
Folate: Cell division, pregnancy (leafy greens, legumes, fortified grains)

sections.title: Essential Minerals
items: Calcium: Bone health, muscle function (dairy, leafy greens, fortified foods)
Iron: Oxygen transport in blood (red meat, spinach, lentils)
Magnesium: 300+ reactions, sleep, muscle (nuts, seeds, whole grains, dark chocolate)
Zinc: Immune function, wound healing (meat, shellfish, legumes)
Potassium: Blood pressure, heart health (bananas, potatoes, beans)
Sodium: Fluid balance (salt - most get too much)
Iodine: Thyroid function (iodized salt, seaweed, fish)

sections.content: The best source of micronutrients: variety of whole foods. Eat the rainbow - different colors provide different nutrients. No supplement replaces real food. Supplements fill gaps, don't replace diet. Most people can get everything from food with varied, colorful diet.

sections.title: Common Deficiencies
items: Vitamin D: Most common, especially in northern climates
Magnesium: 50% of people deficient, stress depletes it
Iron: Especially in women, vegetarians/vegans
B12: Vegetarians/vegans at risk (only in animal products)
Calcium: If not enough dairy or leafy greens
Omega-3s: Most don't eat enough fatty fish
Get tested: Blood work shows deficiencies
Supplement strategically: Target actual deficiencies

sections.title: Food First Approach
items: Colorful vegetables: Different colors = different nutrients
Variety of fruits: Berries, citrus, tropical, stone fruits
Whole grains: B vitamins, minerals
Nuts and seeds: Magnesium, vitamin E, healthy fats
Fatty fish: Omega-3s, vitamin D
Leafy greens: Folate, vitamin K, calcium, iron
Fermented foods: Probiotics, B vitamins
Quality over supplements: Real food has co-factors supplements lack

quiz.question: What's the best way to get micronutrients?
options: Variety of colorful whole foods - eat the rainbow
quiz.explanation: Variety of colorful whole foods provides micronutrients with co-factors supplements lack. Different colors = different nutrients. Supplements fill gaps but don't replace real food.

quiz.question: Which vitamin deficiency is most common?
options: Vitamin D - especially in northern climates
quiz.explanation: Vitamin D deficiency is most common, especially in northern climates with less sunlight. Important for bone health, immune function, mood. Consider supplementation if deficient.

sections.content: Meal planning is secret weapon for consistent healthy eating. Planning prevents last-minute poor choices, saves money, reduces food waste, and reduces decision fatigue. Most people fail at healthy eating not from lack of knowledge but lack of planning. This lesson gives you simple meal planning system that actually works.

sections.title: Benefits of Meal Planning
items: Consistency: Easier to stick with healthy eating
Save money: Less restaurant food, less food waste
Save time: One planning session saves daily decisions
Better nutrition: Balanced meals, not random choices
Less stress: Know what you're eating
Portion control: Pre-portioned prevents overeating
Family friendly: Everyone eats same healthy meals
Weight goals: Easier to track and adjust

sections.title: Simple Planning Process
items: Step 1: Choose 3-5 dinner recipes for week
Step 2: Make shopping list from recipes
Step 3: Shop once for entire week
Step 4: Prep ingredients Sunday (chop vegetables, cook grains, etc)
Step 5: Cook dinner, make extra for lunch next day
Step 6: Simple breakfasts (eggs, oatmeal, yogurt)
Repeat weekly: Gets easier with practice
Keep favorites: Rotate successful meals

sections.title: Meal Prep Strategies
items: Batch cooking: Cook large amounts, portion for week
Ingredient prep: Wash/chop vegetables, cook grains ahead
Protein prep: Cook chicken, hard boil eggs, portion fish
Container system: Glass containers with portions
Freezer friendly: Make double, freeze half
Mix and match: Prep components, combine different ways
2-hour Sunday session: Set aside focused prep time
Start small: Prep 3 days if full week overwhelming

sections.title: Budget-Friendly Tips
items: Buy in bulk: Grains, nuts, seeds cheaper in bulk
Seasonal produce: Cheaper and tastier
Frozen vegetables: Just as nutritious, often cheaper
Canned beans: Convenient, cheap protein source
Eggs: Cheap complete protein
Whole chicken: Cheaper than parts, use for multiple meals
Store brands: Often same quality as name brands
Limit processed: Whole foods usually cheaper per serving

sections.title: Easy Meal Ideas
items: Breakfast: Overnight oats, egg muffins, smoothies, yogurt bowls
Lunch: Big salads with protein, leftover dinner, grain bowls
Dinner: Sheet pan meals, slow cooker, stir-fry, grilled protein + vegetables
Snacks: Nuts, fruit, vegetables + hummus, boiled eggs, cheese
Keep simple: 5-6 ingredients max
Rotate favorites: Don't reinvent every week
Theme nights: Taco Tuesday, Meatless Monday, etc.

quiz.question: What's the main benefit of meal planning?
options: Consistency - prevents last-minute poor choices, reduces decision fatigue
quiz.explanation: Meal planning creates consistency. One planning session prevents week of poor last-minute choices. Reduces decision fatigue, saves time and money, improves nutrition.

quiz.question: How much time should you set aside for meal prep?
options: 2 hours weekly - focused prep session makes week easier
quiz.explanation: 2-hour Sunday prep session covers most of week. Wash/chop vegetables, cook proteins, prepare grains. Front-load effort, coast rest of week.

sections.content: Nutrition labels tell you what's really in your food. Food marketing lies, labels don't (mostly). Learning to read labels helps you avoid hidden sugars, inflammatory oils, and misleading health claims. This skill empowers you to make informed choices. Five minutes learning saves years of poor food choices.

sections.title: Reading the Label
items: Serving size: First thing to check (often smaller than expected)
Servings per container: Multiply values if you eat whole package
Calories: Energy per serving
Macros: Protein, carbs, fat in grams
Fiber: Subtract from total carbs for net carbs
Sugar: Look for added sugars specifically
Sodium: Watch if monitoring blood pressure
Percent Daily Value: Based on 2,000 calorie diet

sections.title: Ingredient List Secrets
items: Order matters: Listed by weight, most to least
Short list better: 5 ingredients usually good
Recognize everything: If you can't pronounce, probably processed
Sugar aliases: 60+ names (high fructose corn syrup, cane juice, dextrose)
Hidden oils: Vegetable, soybean, canola, cottonseed oils
Artificial colors: Red 40, Yellow 5 (avoid)
Preservatives: BHA, BHT, sodium benzoate
Rule: If grandma wouldn't recognize it, reconsider

sections.title: Marketing Tricks
items: 'Natural': Meaningless term, no regulation
'Made with whole grains': Could be 1% whole grain
'Low-fat': Often loaded with sugar
'Sugar-free': Artificial sweeteners instead
'Multigrain': Doesn't mean whole grain
'Lightly sweetened': Still has lots of sugar
'Heart healthy': Based on questionable claims
Trust label, not marketing: Front of package lies, back tells truth

sections.title: What to Look For
items: Protein: At least 10-20g per serving for meals
Fiber: At least 3-5g per serving
Sugar: Less than 5g added sugars per serving
Sodium: Less than 300mg per serving
Fats: Mostly unsaturated, zero trans fat
Ingredients: Whole foods first, short list
Avoid: Partially hydrogenated oils, high fructose corn syrup
Compare: Check multiple brands, choose best option

sections.title: Best Strategy
items: Shop perimeter: Fresh foods don't need labels
Whole foods first: Vegetables, fruits, meat, eggs
Packaged = check label: Always read before buying
Simple test: Less than 5 ingredients, all recognizable
Real food: Single ingredient items (apple, chicken, broccoli)
Compare brands: Find cleanest option
Don't trust claims: Verify with actual label
When in doubt: Choose less processed option

quiz.question: What should you check first on nutrition label?
options: Serving size - often smaller than you expect
quiz.explanation: Check serving size first. Often smaller than expected (like 1/4 cup cereal). Everything else is per serving, so if you eat more, multiply the values.

quiz.question: What does 'natural' on food packaging mean?
options: Meaningless - no regulation, marketing term only
quiz.explanation: 'Natural' is meaningless marketing term with no regulation. Ignore front package claims. Read actual ingredient list and nutrition facts instead.

sections.content: Nutrition industry is full of myths, contradictions, and bad advice driven by profit, not science. Low-fat! No, low-carb! Eat 6 meals! No, fast! Confusing by design. This lesson cuts through nonsense, debunks common myths with science, and gives you clarity on what actually matters for health.

sections.title: Major Myths Debunked
items: Myth: 'Carbs are bad' | Truth: Refined carbs problematic, whole carbs healthy
Myth: 'Fat makes you fat' | Truth: Excess calories make you fat, healthy fats essential
Myth: 'Eating late causes weight gain' | Truth: Total calories matter, not timing
Myth: 'You need to eat 6 small meals' | Truth: Meal frequency doesn't matter, total intake does
Myth: 'Breakfast is essential' | Truth: Optional, depends on individual preference
Myth: 'Diet soda is healthy' | Truth: Artificial sweeteners may disrupt metabolism
Myth: 'Detox diets cleanse toxins' | Truth: Liver and kidneys detox naturally
Myth: 'Supplements can replace diet' | Truth: Whole foods first, supplement gaps only

sections.title: The Calorie Confusion
items: Myth: 'All calories are equal' | Partially true but misleading
Truth: Calorie is energy unit, but sources matter
Protein: Thermic effect (uses 30% of its calories to digest)
Processing: Refined foods digest easier (absorb more calories)
Satiety: 500 calories of chicken satisfies more than 500 of candy
Hormones: Different foods trigger different hormonal responses
Metabolism: Protein preserves muscle, sugar stores as fat
Bottom line: Quality and quantity both matter

sections.title: Organic & Clean Eating
items: Myth: 'Organic is always worth it' | Truth: Priorities matter
Dirty Dozen: Buy organic (strawberries, spinach, apples, grapes, etc)
Clean Fifteen: Conventional fine (avocados, pineapple, onions, etc)
Cost-benefit: Organic vegetables > conventional junk food
'Clean eating': Vague term, focus on whole foods
Pesticides: Washing reduces most residue
Local: Sometimes better than organic shipped far
Don't let perfect stop good: Conventional vegetables beat no vegetables

sections.title: Fasting & Meal Timing
items: Myth: 'Fasting destroys metabolism' | Truth: Short-term fasting may boost metabolism
Intermittent fasting: Can work but not magic
Meal timing: Less important than total intake
Breakfast optional: Listen to your body
Post-workout window: Not as critical as once thought
Eating late: Doesn't inherently cause weight gain
Best schedule: What you can sustain long-term
Individual: Some thrive on fasting, others feel terrible

sections.title: What Actually Matters
items: Consistency: Doing it long-term beats perfect short-term
Whole foods: Minimally processed majority of diet
Adequate protein: 0.8-1g per kg minimum
Vegetables: Multiple servings daily
Hydration: Half body weight in ounces
Sleep: 7-9 hours for hormone regulation
Stress management: Chronic stress sabotages nutrition
Sustainability: If you can't maintain it, it doesn't work

quiz.question: Are all carbs bad for you?
options: No - refined carbs problematic, whole carbs healthy
quiz.explanation: Refined carbs (white bread, sugar) spike blood sugar and provide little nutrition. Whole carbs (vegetables, fruits, whole grains) provide energy, fiber, and nutrients. Quality matters.

quiz.question: Does eating late at night cause weight gain?
options: No - total calories matter, not timing
quiz.explanation: Total calories and quality matter more than timing. Your body doesn't know what time it is. Eating late won't cause weight gain if within calorie needs. Individual schedule matters.
